metadata.titleEn: Long-time built-up land expansion in Hebei, Henan, Shandong, Anhui and Jiangsu,  Beijing and Tianjin from 1990 to 2019
metadata.description:
1) Significance: construction land is one of the highest performance of human activities. The consumption of natural resources and the change of ecological environment can be closely linked with the development of construction land. This data reflects the evolution of high-precision construction land with 30 m spatial resolution from 1990 to 2019 in 7 provinces/municipalities directly under the central government of China, which are also important areas for rapid urbanization.
2) Data sources: Landsat series satellite data; China regional surface meteorological element driven data set (1979-2018)
3) Processing method: supervised classification method is adopted, random forest algorithm and Fourier transform are used to process characteristic bands, and control points are classified based on visual interpretation.
    3-1) Obtaining spectral features: First, screen out Landsat images with transport volume <20%, and superimpose these images in units of 3 years, and then take the median of each superimposed pixel as the target pixel for pixel stitching. Obtain cloud-free images of the entire study area. This method can also better remove the banding influence of Landsat7 data.
     3-2) Acquisition of time features: each pixel that has been superimposed for 3 years is screened for cloud cover, and discrete Fourier transform is performed following the minimum mean square error fitting principle to obtain the time latitude of each pixel. "Crest", "Trough" and "Phase". This method can better eliminate the influence of “bare land” on the extraction of construction land, because bare land may be covered by vegetation in spring and summer, and its time characteristics are quite different from construction land.
     3-3) Extraction of meteorological and terrain features: The meteorological features are calculated from the China Regional Ground Meteorological Elements Driven Data Set (1979-2018): the data set is superimposed at the same time interval as Landsat, and each image is obtained The average value of yuan is used as the meteorological feature (due to the lack of meteorological data for 2019, the meteorological feature of the last period only calculates the average value of 2017 and 2018). Topographic features (elevation, slope) use SRTM-30m data.
The detailed method and code can be seen as follows: https://github.com/wangjinzhulala/North_ China_ Plain_ GEE_ Organized
4) Data quality: the overall accuracy of all years is better than 94%.
5) Application prospects: Simulation of regional urban expansion; estimation of environmental impact of urbanization; quantification of food security and sustainable development.
metadata.instructions: The data is a single TIF file. Its grid contains discrete values of 0-10. Among them, 0 is the background value, 10, 9, 8,..., 1 represents the expansion of built-up land in 1990-1992, 1993-1995, 1995-1997,..., 2017-2019 respectively.

literatureList.titleEn: Mapping Built-Up Land with High Accuracy Using Fourier Transformation and Temporal Correction
literatureList.referenceEn: Wang, J., Hadjikakou, M., Bryan, B. Mapping Built-Up Land with High Accuracy Using Fourier Transformation and Temporal Correction. Preprints 2020, 2020120105 (doi: 10.20944/preprints202012.0105.v1).

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of a dataset focused on construction land expansion in urbanized regions over time?
Feature Specification.Answer: high-resolution spatial data, 30m resolution, time span from 1990 to 2019, Landsat satellite imagery, ground meteorological data, elevation data from SRTM, supervised classification techniques, random forest algorithms, Fourier transform, high accuracy over 94%, cloud-free imagery, temporal characteristics like 'peaks,' 'troughs,' 'phases'

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on urban planning and environmental management if a dataset on construction land expansion in regions like Hebei, Henan, and Shandong is utilized over a 30-year period?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing a dataset on construction land expansion in regions such as Hebei, Henan, and Shandong over a 30-year period can lead to improved urban planning strategies by providing insights into historical trends and patterns of urban growth. This can facilitate predictive modeling of future urban expansion, allowing for better resource allocation and infrastructure development. Additionally, understanding these patterns can help assess the environmental impact of urbanization, aiding in the formulation of policies to mitigate negative effects on ecosystems and promote sustainable development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in using Landsat satellite data to classify and analyze urban land expansion over a region from 1990 to 2019?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves several key steps: First, select Landsat images with cloud cover less than 20% and aggregate them over 3-year intervals. This aggregation helps in creating a cloud-free composite image by taking the median value of each pixel stack. The composite image is then processed using supervised classification techniques, specifically employing the Random Forest algorithm and Fourier Transform to handle spectral feature extraction. Additionally, time series features are extracted through discrete Fourier Transform to identify unique characteristics such as 'peaks,' 'valleys,' and 'phases' of each pixel, which helps differentiate urban land from bare land. Meteorological and topographical features are also incorporated, using data from the Chinese regional surface meteorological elements dataset and SRTM-30m elevation data, respectively. The final classification is validated against visually interpreted control points, achieving an overall accuracy exceeding 94%.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the extraction of high-accuracy construction land expansion timelines from satellite imagery?
Enablement.Answer: The use of supervised classification methods, such as the random forest algorithm combined with Fourier transform for processing spectral bands, enables the extraction of high-accuracy construction land expansion timelines. Control points obtained through visual interpretation are also used in the classification process to ensure accuracy.
